author: peterlabberton
content: A lot of folks rightly shitting on Brian Lucey’s crappy egotist attitude yesterday, but he posted one thing recently that I think really hit the nail on the head, which was something like, “create a world, produce a world, mix a world, keep us in it.” Kind cheesy but honestly I feel like it crystallizes the essence of what a producer (and mixer) should be doing first and foremost. Is the world loose and rough and not technically correct? Great, embrace that! Is the world tight and precise and full-range and punchy? Great, do that! The technical elements should all be just a means of realizing that vision, and a producer is the person who sees that through—whether by doing it themselves, or assembling the right team to make it happen.

author: peterlabberton
content: To put it slightly differently, would The Replacements be better if they made those records today and they sounded “better”? (I honestly don’t know, but I’m not certain they would be.)

author: KushKadett
content: This actually brings me to another point: I think many people ( usually unexperienced) see production issues as something that can and will be fixed during mixing

author: Will Melones
content:
Just transitioned to an M1 MacBook Pro as my ‘desktop’ and I’m still using my old SATA drives for Time Machine and a daily bootable Chronosync backup.

I racked up my drives (probably had 6 total with my desktop) with cheap bays and enclosures something like this:
https://a.co/dbEtaqX
https://a.co/4oTxd3x
I have one ‘disk toaster’ that holds 4 drives, but it doesn’t stay mounted reliably when you start pulling a lot of data, so it’s only in use for one HDD.

And then everything gets backed up offsite to CrashPlan.

author: ehutton21
content: ^this. I recommend an SD storage just because HD drives are really easy to kill. The arm in them will crap out if you need to use it regularly and you can’t insure the files if that happens

author: ehutton21
content: HD Horror story: I stupidly put all data in one basket (ie my hard drive) and never really thought twice. I neglected temperature circumstances, power up options etc. and after 10 months of regular and reliable use, I lost 1.5 TBs of data (many of them being songs and production data) because the motor arm inside the HD was broken and the magnetism of the disk fucked up. I managed to scavenge up old saves of my 3 most valuable songs and 50 GBs of data but it sucked. SDs are more expensive yes, but to get that HD fully repaired would have cost me $900-1200 for a problem that could have been avoided if I spent $200 upfront. So if you can afford it, the more advanced & non mechanical option is better.

author: peterlabberton
content: iZotope de click can be pretty handy to grab most. Then if I’m still hearing ‘em, I’ll mostly solve those issues by zooming in super super close, finding the spikes from the clicks, and either a) copying over wave forms from right before or after that look the same, and then cross fading/clip gaining to blend in, or b) grabbing the pencil tool and just fuggin’ drawing a new wave form over the high frequency shit. Option b really only works if it’s like, one cycle of fucked up-ness. I’m often surprised what I can get away with. I’m sure there are better ways to do this, but this has (mostly) worked for me.

author: Zeuswayn3
content: I’m really curious to hear this discords opinion on being a jack-of-trades vs master of one.

author: ALXCPH
content: I think both are viable to make a career in music. But if you want to be the best at one thing, you’ll have to focus mainly on that thing. I’m of the opinion of doing what you enjoy and hopefully somebody want to pay you to do that thing. This is really a business where there is no one correct path

author: ALXCPH
content: Look at someone like Jon, he used to record and produce, but he enjoyed mixing the most and then went full in on that at got to where he is today. Compare that with @oaklandmatt he is always wearing 3 hats at once, but he is still a master at those things and makes a living doing what he loves.

author: ALXCPH
content: In short, do what you enjoy, but do it a shit ton so you’ll get good.

author: BatMeckley
content: Why not just master all of em?

author: ehutton21
content: I feel like, especially in music where there’s so much overlap between positions, you should do everything until people seek you out enough for one specific thing that it makes sense to specialize

author: ehutton21
content:
People love to say “oh you can’t make it unless you focus on what you do best,” but I feel like that only applies to a situation where doing more than one thing is taking someone who could be a good specialized worker and forcing them to be a mediocre engineer, producer, and whatever else. 

If you’re doing more than one thing at a high level, keep it up until you feel yourself specifically suffering from a time crunch. I mean matt sounds like he’s loosely cycled through periods where he’s a mixer, then a producer, then a writer. You don’t have to juggle, you can sequence your trades.

author: ehutton21
content: But everyone really benefits if there’s at least one person in the room who speaks every individual’s language, so I say just do what you love with the music and don’t worry too much if you’ve got the bills figured out.

author: BatMeckley
content: My experience has been every facet of this world I’ve worked in has informed every other facet in a really positive way, to the point where I wouldn’t have had the success I’ve had in any of them if I hadn’t tried all of them.

author: BatMeckley
content: It sounds weird but literally wiggle it around when you re-detect. Also wiggle the blob to the left and the right to make sure you get the connecting lines right. Also by all accounts from your other takes it looks like the note it’s supposed to be is a step and a half lower. You might not be getting a good pitch line because you’re trying to tell it it’s the wrong note.

author: noahc
content: For the multi instrumentalist producers, how do you guys get better at multiple instruments? It takes so much time to improve on just one instrument. Finding the time in between actually making music is tricky and am equally average at most instruments. But can edit the shit out of it. 🤣

author: peterlabberton
content: (That said getting serious chops on one instrument certainly helps playing simple stuff!)

author: noahc
content: Turned into a good mix engineer by trying to make basic things sound good so that where my focus has gone over the years.

author: Eric Martin
content: as an adult, you’d be surprised what just 15 minutes a day doing a thing will help long term, take an hour and practice something actually challenging for 15 on each thing you want to be better at

author: Eric Martin
content: always practice things that challenge you, play for fun later and that will help but working on things you can’t do slowly and methodically until you can do them slow, slowly speed up the tempo, might take a year to get better at drums, but you did it and long term a year is nothing

author: ALXCPH
content: And just play a lot. Getting good at an instruments is just as much developing your ears as it is technique.

author: BatMeckley
content: Record yourself. Constantly. Part of the reason we get so much better so much faster while playing with other people is we lose the ability to bullshit ourselves that something is good when it’s not. I did this little run of instagram videos of me playing solely to hold myself accountable. Stuff I thought I had initially really sounded hideous to me the second I considered playing it for anyone.

author: BatMeckley
content: I’m so tired I legitimate read that as “A minus list producer” and thought “hey that sounds like me!”

author: Zack Hames
content:
So true.

I had a teacher who told me to play as slowly as needed to play correctly.

Because The more you fuck up trying at a faster speed, the more you’re building memory to keep fucking it up.

author: Will Melones
content:
This this this. Resist perfecting the ability to play it wrong. I realized way after music school that the best practice for me was mapping out every finger move like it was choreography, and practicing those super deliberate plans in small isolated groups.

I get the impression this is just like avoiding injury at the gym. Or, uh, so I hear…

author: Zakhiggins
content: @noahc at the end of the day you're training a muscle to do a movement - just like if you wanted to improve any other physical attribute, just get into a routine and be very consistent with it. Do all the things mentioned by the guys above in your routine. As @Eric Martin said, you'd be very surprised where 15 mins a day will get you after a few weeks/months

Hey everyone, 

I've been working on an idea for a studio tool and officially just launched a Kickstarter to bring it to life. It's basically a deck of cards that creates short prompts/sentences that you respond to and musically interpret. Think drawing Tarot meets Eno's Oblique Strategies. I've had a couple test decks made up and they've been great in the studio writing and using them with bands as well and I think they might be useful to some of you all on here so I wanted to share. ✌️

content: Can't say I'm a man for using stereo subs in my productions though lol

author: ALXCPH
content: If the tracks are well mastered/mixed, you don’t need to make individual eq adjustments. If a track is completely out of whack, you can always dial it back some.

author: ALXCPH
content: Also also also always have a backup way of that set. So once you got everything sounding how you like. Make a mp3 or wav export of the whole set, as one file and as individual tracks to have on a usb and on your phone as a backup incase ableton or your laptop wants fuck you over.

author: jonmatteson
content: Turn everything down a bit so you are averaging -18 rms on each track and tweak from there by ear. This way nothing will clip the output of your interface and you can have some headroom to turn stuff up if you need to.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Re: BB Tubes and gain matching:

I was curious if there was any sort of gain matching because I had noticed while using it recently that I was having to compensate output even on low settings.  Just decided to test with pink noise and Volume Buddy (great tool from Noir Labs if you use Ableton Suite for auto-gain matching).

author: Adam Thein
content:
Not the clearest pictures here but:

Just instantiating you get a 0.4db boost.
Beauty at 3, no beast, you are up 1.9db
Beauty at 5, no beast, you are up 2.9db
Beauty at 1, Beast at 1, you are up 1.8db

I like the colors it has but just be aware it's not auto-leveling at all for the added harmonics, it really is getting louder

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s interesting to me how little I get from the Terrace clip and how much the Rick Rubin clip resonates for me. The swagger/I been wronged/they all slept on me/I’m the genius overtones are incredibly boring and kind of ugly to me. A huge part of it is cultural, in Ireland that kind of talk is just socially unacceptable, almost to a fault. And the flip is that Terrace came up in a very different environment

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But it’s more than that. Rubin’s humility in the face of great music matches my experience

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve watched it come through people, and seen and heard some extraordinary things. Setting the ego aside seems to raise the odds of the muse showing up in my 28 years of doing music

author: Slow Hand
content: For me, the takeaway from that Terrace clip is that he saw an institution that didn't respect the craft of musicians, and so he set out to cultivate a scene of collaborators that respected the people who committed themselves wholeheartedly to the art form but don't want to play the game of interpersonal relations to a point where it also compromises the art and diminishes it's potential.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That makes sense. I get that some people also need a kind of oppositional energy to be motivated. Re the institution that doesn’t respect the craft It’s a really interesting puzzle to solve. So much of what we do is undervalued in some way by the business. I meet people literally daily who are confused by the supremacy of Serban/Manny/Spike, as though decisions to hire them were based on Sonics. People are often buying different things than we are selling. This has been made painfully clear to me in the acoustics space.

author: Slow Hand
content:
That said, I greatly respect Rick's perspective and his viewpoint mirrors my own more than most people who I've met in my personal relations. I admire his openness and need to hold things lightly. To keep things consistently in flux and open to shifting interpretation.

I suppose the challenge comes in reconciling both views and finding a way for them to coexist.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Terrace did hint at that, where the ability to play nice with a team is more valuable than raw chops

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Both approaches work, no doubt. At this phase of life I am more interested in stuff than annoys me or pushes my buttons, there’s often some heat there, and potential for growth

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Endlessly consuming ideas that feel nice, satisfying and resonant is a recipe for atrophy. And only consuming stuff that pushes my buttons is unsustainable too 🙂 so I try to find a balance

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And mostly fail! I find myself bored or annoyed too often

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Doesn’t make for a good soundbite though

author: Slow Hand
content: There's little hope for those who won't put in the effort to understand.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I agree with this 100%. I spent some time with Justin Timberlake and was astounded at his ability to move through connecting socially, political work and actually mixing

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve been super impressed by so many people at that level, what it really takes to sustain

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Every time I’ve gotten close to someone at that level it becomes crystal clear that it’s no accident

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's funny. For all of the difficulties in producing transcendent records, I have nothing but respect for the filmmakers that I love. Their work is at least two orders of magnitude more complicated than any record.

I am astounded by the willpower and judgement of those people when I think about what it takes for them to make a movie. I can only fathom the obstacles that they have to navigate to realize their vision. It makes me grateful that I only make records. At least I don't have to contend with the political and economic nightmare that *they're* dealing with.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Even my limited work in TV gave me enough insight into that world to mostly agree, although I see the challenges as pretty different

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s an intimacy to record making that is not present on a shoot, and there are coordination and vision challenges in film/TV that make band politics look like child’s play

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But I remember leaving the theater alone after watching the 2nd Lord of the Rings movie and I could not process how any one man, even with the best team, could hold it all in his head

author: popaganda.
content: It’s a motivation thing. Lots of times when I’m creating I speak/feel in hyperbole. “This is the best thing I’ve ever heard/this fucking sucks” when you’re in the zone it’s about making a bunch of yes/no decisions….finding the right note. And part of that is rejecting the “wrong” notes. The way Terrace interpreted Herbie’s advice was that the LA tour/audition scene was not for him. So he created a community of extremely musical, different, nerdy guys that are now such an important part of the fabric of culture. Not sure if they’d be where they are without that chip on the shoulder.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There’s no checklist- but a discussion is always had about vision. Sometimes it’s me pitching ideas sometimes fielding them, sometimes is collaborative, but we almost always have a clear idea before begin. And part of that conversation is who will be involved (and how much it’ll cost.) 
In my case 7/10 times people are hiring me for my vision, 3/10 for my ability to help them realize theirs. I have enough experience in every stage of the process to know and am a good enough communicator to outline what it will likely look like. 
BUT, the real assignment is to be open to the muse, which will only ever find you working, ya know?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Was there a conversation here about improv before? Searching that term in this server just turns up a bunch of nerds harping on about how things got better when they ditched their Focals and bought Neumanns.

I took a few consecutive courses in it over the last few years, discovered one of my favourite performance mediums. When you watch it done well, live in the flesh, it’s unlike anything else. The mindset is a great facilitator of play.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It’s come up once or twice. I couldn’t agree with you more. It’s such a wonderful, playful way of being in the world and I strongly recommend it to anyone who’s willing to dive in. It’s so enriching.

Skilled improv comics are such a marvel to witness, not to mention a pleasure. It’s unbelievable.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Absolutely. I get a different kind of overwhelmed/mind boggled sensation watching good improv than anything else.

For any London krew, I can recommend The Free Association in Haggerston. They have regular shows (several weekly) at the De Beauvoir Arms, and run their courses from the same location. You’ll see faces you recognise from national TV shows etc getting up there in front of 30 people and winging it. It’s incredible.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think they nailed it. Massive X had a rocky launch, so people still tend to give the team shit for it, but I think NI have distilled all of the best elements from their decades of design and DSP into an extremely well-rounded instrument.

The GUI is massive and will blot out your entire laptop monitor, though. There's also a pretty big learning curve for absolute beginners, but it's worth it.

author: Ross Fortune
content: I suppose another advantage of massive X would be that with the user base being as broad as it likely is, there’s probably a heap of resources for learning it. And maybe holdovers that still apply from the original.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. It has a great manual if you want to dive into it. Also, NI are really filling out the educational component lately. Last week they dropped this 90 minute video giving a module-by-module tour of the instrument. It's not as deep as I'd like, but it's solid: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYzagFV0eLM

author: Adam Thein
content: I'm really bad at it, don't like it, and really would like to pass off productions to mixers when I can in the future personally.  I tend to get really lost in the details in this step and can sometimes get completely derailed.  If anyone has tips to avoid this I'd love to hear!

author: bennythetweet
content: I’ve felt the same way but started printing stems, saving new version to force a line between production and mixing - Leveraging “Out of sight, out of mind” principle. The qty of stems may vary depending on the level of detailed mixing expected. But, I see GrammyCian is typing so just ignore this.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I've yet to have anyone take tracks I recorded and do something I was excited with, it's a bummer. (I am not working at the high level of, tracking a great band, handing off tracks to a great mixer).

I'll record multitrack drums for a song, I'll even do quite a bit of sweetening and make it sound damn mixed before I hand it off then i hear the final product....and it sounds thing and harsh and bad and sad 😦

I hope someday i get to work with a mixer that I just get to sit back and go "Fuck yeah this rules, I don't know how you did this but it's gold"

author: GaspardMurph
content: I still don’t understand why people do that… If you have nothing on your master, pressing the record enable button on any track defeats any latency or delay comp on that track (except for what is induced by the plugins ON the recording track and H/W buffer size) but routing to a Virtual Chanel in Console will not change that.

author: GaspardMurph
content: Sorry I feel like I sound like dick @Ross Fortune

author: GaspardMurph
content: I’m just saying if you have nothing going on your master fader in pro tools, and you aren’t running the track you want to record on into an aux then latency is only a question of buffer size and latency induced by plugins on the said track.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, I’ve loathed the people that are like “SEE WHAT IM BRINGING TO THE TABLE?? THE VALUE?!”

It’s probably (definitely?) stunted my career but I’ve always just tried to let the work speak for itself, and the people you want to work with will notice.

It kinda goes back to the “if you have to say ‘do you know who I am’, you’re probably not famous enough to say ‘do you know who i am’” thing. Which I will admit, these days especially, is not a particular popular stand to take.

author: austenballard
content:
Okay here's my analogy

I often feel, working with digital audio tools, like I'm trying to build a house with a pile of bricks, but they're painted entirely black and I don't know what they're made of, and don't have a way to find out.

Are they strong enough to stack up without falling down? Are they waterproof? Soundproof? Are they firm or will they crack under the weight of the roof? Are they secretly made from some composite material that will catch fire?

I don't know. But I know they're bricks, and I know roughly what I can do with bricks, and I have to build my house. So I build my house and then just wait to see what problems show up.

author: austenballard
content:
Imagine if other industries let the people who make their tools get away with the kind of chicanery that goes on in ours. 

Construction? Medicine? Transport? When buildings fall down, or drugs turn out to be carcinogenic, or planes start falling out of the sky there are inquests and hearings and lawsuits.

But I guess "this is only music," so what does it matter if the people making our equipment are being misleading.

author: austenballard
content: Anyway, that's my rant. I just wish this field had a little less voodoo. That's a big part of why I appreciate this community. We have experts with deep practical knowledge, people willing to dive in and test stuff, and a general willingness among everyone to engage with questions in a way that seeks to find truth and not just parrot  MDIC-sponsored One Weird Tricks

author: NoahNeedleman

Assisting a top level mixer for a couple years I learned the most important thing is this:
He won’t let something out that doesn’t sound, to his ears, completely professional.  I watched him turn utter turds into songs that sounded important. And he’d do it time and time again. He’d bitch about it, but he’d do it, EVERY TIME. 
There is a matter of taste of course, but everyone called him The Wolf (Harvey Keitel Pulp Fiction,) because no matter how bad it was, he’d fix it.

author: JustinLeu
content: Hey guys, Im tracking a live record right now that we want to supplement the congregation with some choir/gangvox (probably 15-20 people will be tracked) what are your favorite ways to do this? Mostly in terms of having to use a wedge and minimizing the bleed of it. A few years ago I did something similar and tracked the choir then left everything in place and tracked just the wedge to polarity invert the track later. It did cancel pretty well but just wondered if anyone had any other tips for this kind of thing! Thanks guy!

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Angling the wedge and rolling top end off it is crucial. That and the amount of level you send it will impact the level of bleed.

hi there
thoughts on the neutron 3 assistant algorithm ? i think it does too much by default which is understandable, but what strikes me every time is how it makes everything sound like cheap 80s stuff. after thinking about this for a few seconds, that's probably due to the hi end boost it does everytime on everything, and my sound quality from the start

author: popaganda.
content: Probably easier to just treat the sound the way your gut tells you. But if you try it and it’s cool then great! Happy accident.

author: BatMeckley
content: +1 for happy accident. Get your mix good, slap it on there, see what happens. Neat thing about digital is if it’s trash, you just take it off, no harm done. Worse case scenario seeing what it tries to do to your sound can give you maybe some insight or a different perspective on how to treat your mix/production yourself that you might’ve not otherwise come up with yourself.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I'm sorry but I can't agree with this. 

@Deleted User what is the context of this production ?

author: Edward Rivera
content: You can first suggest that they Re-record it, and you can be of *light* guidance, no one likes to be micromanaged

author: Edward Rivera
content: Putting the onus on you to replay the part is the very last thing you'd suggest, *if at all* that would be like pushing someone aside so you can show them how to fuck their wife

author: Edward Rivera
content: At the very least, if they *are* happy with what they have, it's on you to detach your ego from it. It's not your record

author: Edward Rivera
content: Given the context, I stand behind what I say. It's my understanding you've been in certain situations that required you to do the exact opposite of what I'm proposing, and I've been there too. But seeing as this isn't one of those situations, then it doesn't need to go down that road

author: Edward Rivera

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I've been incredibly lucky to have been train by Steve, and before so had a similar community to grow up in which formed like minded beliefs even before meeting. 

Replaying something is a desperate move that is made in certain situations where stakes are high, and the way it was explained, didn't seem like a particularly high stakes situation where people's jobs and reputations were on the line

author: Edward Rivera
content: I don't feel like anything I said was "exclusive" but if profanity is frowned upon here, then I will refrain from it in order to continue contributing to this community

author: BatMeckley
content: A little phase gonna be less noticeable than abrupt pop. The other trick is set nudge to 1 ms and push the last one a couple clicks right. Zoom in on the fade and watch the shape of it change as you nudge milliseconds to the right. One will line up best and you wont have the phasiness. Also that is such a short fade that without question people are more likely to gloss over the phasiness than they are an audible pop.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As an alternative to reverb, I really enjoy the sound of the Michael Norris FFT plugins that smear and stretch audio (spectral blur, spectral smooth, etc). They all have an option to *randomize phase*, which instantly makes the sound *very* diffuse. And, bonus(!), this also collapses into mono very well. That said, they're a unique flavor that you're not going to get anywhere else.

Though last time I checked, they're fairly buggy and don't have a very robust support. So they may not be that useable, depending on your DAW of choice.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Sounds fun! 

*Timeless 3* and *Saturn 2* both have this super-neat *dynamics* knob, which operates like a one-knob compressor/gate. Turned to the left it functions like a gate and makes the signal tighter. Turned to the right it blows out all of the dynamics.

Timeless has this feature inserted into the delay line which allows you to sculpt the echoes in a very musical way. I suspect could be very cool to play around with in your verb algorithms.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
my opinion, people worry way too much about gain staging and i dont spend much time thinking about it. 

if shit is hitting your master bus at +20db, throw a utility on at -20db and youll be fine.

now the level in between each plugin, is something to be aware of. but only in that you dont want that to be too far over 0. dont worry about getting it into a perfect range.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
also i used to have a similar thing with the 2 oppsoite utility devices around saturators and clippers. However, i realized it was making me way too conservative with how much i was clipping and saturating things. Part of the beauty of those techniques is precisely that it makes it loud without changing the peak level. 

Especially with producing, just let it be loud and have fun with it. If you need to turn down what comes out of that Saturator plugin, just trim down that Output knob.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: An analogy I’ve been working on lately

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Music is conversation

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: How many people do you know personally that are good conversationalists? Probably quite a few. The kind of person who can go deep over a glass of wine, or strike up a conversation in a line at the post office

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Now, how many people do you know that can compellingly craft *both* sides of a conversation and have it feel authentic, interesting and even artful?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Very little writing rises to that level, it’s rare because it’s really hard to do. Some playwrights, screenwriters and authors can pull it off but it’s not typically possible for us normies

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think music is like that. *Way* more people have what it takes to engage in interesting musical conversation live with others. People who can build compelling or true feeling works track by track, Lego brick by Lego brick are much much rarer

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So why have we made the latter the modern default?

author: LAPhill
content:
Yes, and not all music benefits from live tracked. I had a whole thing about that but deleted it because it was obfuscating my point. 

Where I take issue is when it's used as a crutch, or because someone doesn't realize how much better it can be. An orchestral mockup is a very detailed ransom note, cobbled out of thousands of disparate letters from different magazines and strung together in some semblance of order. Ask a violinist to read the sentence you wrote and suddenly it means something.

author: LAPhill
content: But Hans Zimmer can craft a piece of of samples, with no live people, crafted with intention and sounds more alive than when some local orchestra goes and does the live-to-picture concert.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: He’s the one in a million though, a Mutt Lange

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: They exist, but maybe that way of working is not as useful for mortals

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Or said another way - people see Hans and think “I’m gonna get a bunch of samples and kill it like him” but what they really need is his past musical experiences IRL

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: (And maybe his charisma 🙂

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Back to “the greats do this but doing this won’t make you great”

author: LAPhill
content: Or the way Son Lux manipulated recordings for Everything Everywhere? I'm just saying that there are a million valid ways to make music, and I don't want my words about the benefits of tracking together or live performances to be seen as everything else being "less than." But 19 times out of 20, I'm going to pick working with real people in a real way.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
It was 2005, I was 18, and I had no idea how intense it was going to be. I was trying to buy a chai tea before going back to my tent that morning, but when I reached into my pocket to pay, my wallet wasn’t there, and when I looked down… neither was my pocket.

The lady was nice and gave me the chai tea on karma anyway.

I discovered that I very much liked that kind of approach to festivals, and repeated those kinds of escapades many times over the next 7/8 years until the great scales of fun : regret began to shift toward an unfavourable balance. 

I’m much more chill now, in every way. Love a headphone in a room.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I respectfully disagree.
I’ve long been on record as saying the only reason I’ve had a sustained career is due to my diversity in ability and interests, and how they each inform the others. If you only eat potatoes, you’re fucked when the potato famine hits.

author: BatMeckley
content: The fact that you had the balls and the drive to write to him says a lot about your character and chances for success. The making your own luck bit and all that. Doesn’t mean it’s always going to work, but you greatly increase your chances of having something rad happen.

author: peterlabberton
content: I mean it less in the sense of super specializing, more in the sense of embracing one’s own taste and not trying to hit the middle of the bell curve. More as an answer to “why hire you over Serban (or Aaron Sterling or Jack Antonoff)”.

author: BatMeckley
content: That I back. Another one of my go to bits is “be a broken clock”. If you’re chasing what you hear on the radio you’re always gonna be 6 months to two years behind (the amount of time it took for that to come out). If you plant a flag where you are and get awesome at the thing you love you’re gonna be EXACTLY right twice a day. The tides of musical taste are always churning, be awesome at your thing and the world will rotate underneath you and you’ll be exactly right at least sometimes.

author: BatMeckley
content: Nels a great example of doing his thing and well.

content: (Clearly I’d been texting with Ruairi when I wrote that 😂)

author: LAPhill
content: Basically nothing you hear in a film is captured on set. Depending on the film, much of the dialogue is recorded later, too.

author: Josh
content: I ALWAYS WANTED TO KNOW IF THEY OVERDUB DIALOGUE OFTEN

author: LAPhill
content: Unless the scene is indoors with no machinery or noise making things around, it’s hard to get clean dialogue. Wind, explosions, cars, animals.. all make it hard to capture. Typically, actors wear a lav mic in addition to there being a sound person with a shotgun mic, but it’s still very challenging to get useful dialogue on a lot of situations. (I’m told. I’m just the music guy)

author: LAPhill
content: Also, anytime an actor is giving a line and you can’t see their mouth? Almost guaranteed the line you’re hearing was not the line they’re saying.

author: Josh
content: That’s what I always thought. Because the logistics of recording clean audio with multiple camera angles or multiple takes seems hard.

author: LAPhill
content: Eh, the not-seeing-their-mouth thing is usually because someone wants to change what they're saying. You'd be surprised how drastically things get altered/re-written in post.

author: Will Melones
content: Or if it’s a clip from an interview, the producers re-constructed the quote to tell their narrative

author: LAPhill
content: Yep. Watch one minute of any reality TV show to hear the egregious, sloppy edit version of this.

author: sethearnest
content: One of the deepest examples I've read about: apparently ALL of Elijah Woods' dialogue as Frodo in LOTR is ADR.

author: LAPhill
content: I believe this is because much of those films was shot at a slightly altered frame rate so things appear a little slower. The dialogue would have had to all be slowed down and sound very lethargic, so they re-recorded it.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Among many nuggets of wisdom on here Ruairi, this has to be the best and deepest one for me. This consideration of what deep value we bring. It’s no exaggeration to say it’s totally changed how I think about what I do and how to do it after a year plus spent deeply considering it.

Sonically I am what I am, hopefully improving all the time but I think there is so much more value we can add if we are intentional about it.

Mainly knowing when something is “good/done” or rather that I love it and recognize that others may too. And how to articulate that behind the scenes, reasons why. Deep topic. Applies to any role I think but especially production, knowing when an idea is worth pursuing

In regards to AI, who knows. But I know understanding it as deeply as possible and being on the bleeding edge of using it, or understanding how others are using it to create amazing art is useful for us all!

author: masteredbyjack
content: As an aside, I know we are in production talk here — but gotta believe if you can become a monster at all the intangibles behind the scenes you’re gonna be set up for a long and successful career no matter where the trends and roles in the business go

author: rse
content: does the polarity of a kickdrum for example actually matter (not in relation to anything else!). Just a single kickdrum, will it make an audible difference if the speaker moves forward or backwards on the initial transient? I know some techno and psy-trance producers who swear by having positive transients, that make the speakers move forward first, but honestly I'm not 100% convinced our ears and bodies are even able to notice this difference

author: David Fuller
content: Personally I don't hear it making much difference but I suppose it could

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: My experience IRL and based on a lot of reading is that while it does make a difference in a given room, on a given set of speakers in a given position in the room - the sense of what is “better” is not stable when you change any of those variables

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So you can spend time optimizing in your room only to find that the opposite actually sounds better elsewhere

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That said, I endeavor wherever possible to get absolute phase correct on speaker systems

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And of course if you are recording live big bands you need this locked throughout the chain so you can make sensible micing decisions

content: https://youtu.be/_LftgfoRWqI?si=n6raXfmykehKC3cP watching this video again and I was wondering and maybe wanna ask the room how you would approach „pushing“ a musician to their full potential? I feel like 30 or so years after this clip was shot we have a evolved a bit and hopefully strayed away a bit from a toxic studio attitude and insulting/becoming personal towards ppl we produce. I was wondering if any of you could share some stories or could give advice on how to make sure musicians live up to their full potential/helping them when they‘re clearly stuck etc. but inside using positive affirmation and language without making them feel inferior/insulting them or bein passive aggressive?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think a lot about the fact that we inherited a world built by often unsavory people, or at least people who we judge by today’s behavior standards as being out of order

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Niceness? Or lack of it?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Abuse is not a panacea

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ever see how soldiers talk to each other, real soldiers in documentaries?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: They abuse each other highly, but the mission and trust is solid

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think if you find yourself over and over feeling frustrated then it’s a failure to communicate mission properly, I’ve struggled with this forever

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This is really the job of the producer

author: Edward Rivera
content:
Quite the opposite. Much like in life, I think we can find ways to extract what we need from people while also providing value to them in a positive way. That doesn't mean we need to stifle ourselves by verbally dancing around issues, but we need to find new ways to communicate 

I agree with @cian riordan about everything that was said. That production style was born out of cultural context and probably needed at the time

But then again Nirvana made great fucking records without any of that Tom foolery...and not just talking about Steve...I'd hardly put Butch in the same box as Bob

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think if I’ve got your back, if we want the same thing, and you *really* know it then permission to speak much more honestly comes along for the ride

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And yet, as someone who was enthralled by Nirvana they were shit role models as men

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I wish I’d had better

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: DG has gone on to be a G no doubt

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: No real judgement on any of them, all humans just trying to get through

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And no judgement on young me for being enthralled

author: Slow Hand
content:
On the flip side, I was talking to my therapist yesterday about how 15 years of me working with musicians has accustomed me to delivering feedback in a positive, constructive, non-confrontational manner. The kind of bedside manner in which I'm not leveling pointed feedback at performers and writers out of concern for crushing their confidence or resolve.

I still think that's an important skill, but I was hypothesizing that having spent so much time dealing with people in this way has made me less likely to push others in a very direct way to get what I need and to communicate when they are not delivering in the way that meets my expectations. And that's bled over into my personal relationships.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: You just put my struggle perfectly to words

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: I don‘t have it in me to potentially crush someones confidence bc I know how it feels myself

author: Slow Hand
content: Funnily, I am extremely comfortable *receiving* harsh feedback. I welcome it and appreciate it. Doesn't phase me a bit.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Being inoffensive is not a mission

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And if you have a mission, you’d better interrogate it well before trying to get people onboard

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If everyone on a team really believes in what you are all about then warm and fuzzies come second, they are for the after party once you’ve achieved your goal

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I wasted 45 years of my life worrying about being liked all the time

author: Rollmottle
content: this is something i struggle with everyday as an older professional with newer-to-professional-life folks...my "harshness" (it's not) is often construed as "dick." i am not a dick.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s a generational divide there no doubt, I feel it often

author: Slow Hand
content: I think this is spot on. Having a shared mission is crucial to making sure that everyone is aiming at the same target. Even if they're pointed in the same general direction, those tiny differences in vision will diverge more and more over time if there's not a vivid description of what we're all striving for.

author: Slow Hand
content: It's such a valuable thing to have someone who can continually be providing definition to the goal. Who knows where we're all going and can communicate that every step of the way.

author: river
content:
Something I keep thinking of is;
What is "being nice"

And to go back to the original question, I think being nurturing is a great way to make sure someone can live up to their full potential. That includes being honest. 
Beating around the bush, or an omission of your subjective opinion, is that kind? I think being able to say your truth, with tact, and in due time, is a great skill

author: river
content: Also when to "give up" (with acceptance and willingness to) Vs "giving in" (involuntary) to ideas and beliefs is something I think about a lot

content: There's various points on both sides that I truly agree with. But Matthew is simply asking, "are there other ways ?" And the consensus of which I don't agree with seems to be "nope, you gotta push" but why can't we pull ?

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was just trying to illustrate the point that in this specific comment “You can do your not-so-best work, treat people square, and still get the next gig. You can make a hit record with someone, treat them like shit, and lose the next gig” that for the most part, in my experience that doesn’t hold true. If you make a hit, even if you were shitty, you’re more likely to get the gig, than if you did your not so best work and treated them great. 

But that it CERTAINLY shouldn’t have to be an either or situation. 
(I really liked your personal trainer analogy if you need some agreeing mixed in 🩵)

author: Slow Hand
content: Sounds like you may have a limiter or compressor with unlinked stereo channels. So when the right side of the mix is hitting the limiter it will turn the right channel down and make the left channel sound louder by comparison. Hence the feeling that the mix is getting pulled to the left.

author: Slow Hand
content: The answer in this case would be to link your L/R channels on the compressor or limiter so that both channels get turned down by the same amount.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is a great question. Good answers so far, but think about it like this:
When editing, It doesn’t matter which part of the transient you choose, *just be consistent* in that choice. Once everything is gridded so it sounds consistent and played in time, consolidate that region and try slipping the whole thing forward or backward until the *pocket* feels right. 
Generally, if there are drums, once you get that locked & feeling great, that’s your North Star, and every other instrument is guided by that.

content: This is huge. You gotta make sure you do it the whole time or else it’s gonna be worse than if you didn’t edit it.

author: spectrummasters
content: Not to take anything away from super unknown and Michael , buttttttt …..badmotorfinger is for me , the zenith of sound gardens work building on the pure gritty brilliance of ok mega and louder than love . Superunknown felt like the start of the  end of the Seattle sound for. Me , I think at that time nirvana had turned in in utero and I think the difference between heart shaped box and superunknown demonstrated nirvana were sticking with their aesthetic but sound garden were sadly drifting . They lost some of their menace with superunknown imho . Jesus Christ pose and outshined on the other hand ? You could demolish buildings with badmotorfinger

author: BatMeckley
content: It’s not that badmotorfinger is bad, it’s AWESOME. It’s just with Superunkown they went from angry to art. They really opened up their horizons. Everybody leans on Black Hole Sun, and deservedly so, but for my money My Wave is one of the most beautiful pieces of music ever put to tape.

author: BatMeckley
content: It felt an awful lot like when the Downward Spiral came out, and it became harder and harder to pigeonhole these musical geniuses as just angry young dudes. There was just a depth to the vision that I sadly don’t see nearly as much these days

content: @hendrick The feeling of the rhythm honestly. How does the phrase feel in conjunction with the rest of the line and with the production or the moment that’s happening. At that point, the rhythm may be different or slightly off, but as long as it feels good and it’s not too out of whack, I leave it, and don’t get lost in the 20 takes of the same line. It’d be semantics beyond that. Cause then you’d be like “we’ll he/she said ‘love’ 0.2 samples behind this one.”

author: Deleted User
content: these are things I am posing for Rob to consider- also wanted to know where he is at with understanding of timing and ensemble to get an idea of what would be the next step for Rob

author: Deleted User
content:
Also. As a musician recording the take, I found that trying to correct timing as I’m playing ends up with worse results post-editing vs just being flat out wrong. Meaning if I am off, it ends up being easier to edit if i continue being off until the end of the phrase. I could just nudge the whole thing, and it will be perfect. If I correct myself mid phrase, I will end up having to move thing note by note - which frankly would be better off doing another take. 

Just like how stable flat or sharp note is so much easier to fix in a natural way than fixing “unstable but on pitch sometimes” notes

And this is because there are two different timings

The time feel in relation to everyone else

The internal time feel of individual musicians in the ensemble. 

While both things need to be considered, for recording - it’s usually better to prioritize the latter when things are off. Making things fit together that have solid internal time is much easier and less work than making everything that fit together sometimes, but then don’t other times. 

But this only matters if you are the one playing the instruments. If you’re just editing, then the question comes down to does it need to be re-played or frankensteined

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Would be worth asking more questions before offering advice.

author: Rob Domos
content: A very close friend of mine with a whole wall full of grammy noms sat me down to talk about this early on in our friendship. She said “you remind me a lot of *mutual friend xyz*; He’s way better than me at music but he hasn’t even had a tenth of the career I’ve had because he spent his whole life trying to make a masterpiece. It’s a shame, and I don’t want to see that happen to you. You gotta have the humility to know that music isn’t that serious, and that making songs isn’t all that different from making donuts. Don’t be like him Rob. Just make the fucking donuts.”

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Piggybacking on the convo that happened a bit before in #📟biz-talk regarding how to not conduct yourself when facing injustice as a live musician:
If you think of a producer that’s booked simply because of their presence and/or them simply being in the room rather then their technical skill or ability, what do you think are the most valuable and obvious attributes a person like this should have in your opinion?

author: Zack Hames
content: @Josh is bang on, only thing I could add is ability to communicate emotionally and get performances out of musicians.

author: Deleted User
content: the ability to create space where everyone can be at their best

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻

author: BatMeckley
content: An ability to reach the back of the console without a step ladder.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’ve been trying to find a sweet spot in not over giving but giving enough for people to work with or ponder on. 

I’ve been very prone to making the mistake of over giving (maybe that is a nicer way of putting it..), and has experienced it making it worse in every possible way. Singer losing confidence, in their head not in tune with their mind body spirit. 

sometimes I just gotta shut up and let them feel it for themselves because they already know what they need to do. Sometimes they are too zoomed in and need someone to take them out of the zoom and say “you did good” or “that part is tunable, we can move on”, sometimes it helps to tell them what to do. Gauging the receptiveness is important, receptiveness doesn’t always mean they need the feedback either. 

btw This is just me listing what I’ve been thinking about and wanting to improve

author: Adam Thein
content:
Order some Sennheisers and try them for a while and be open to sending them back.  You can always order 990s if you don’t like them.  People’s descriptions of sound may not translate to your experience because all of our physiology are different and your brain has been wired to the 990 signature for 4+ years now.

That being said if you give yourself some time to learn the Senns I’m sure they’d work for you.  They are generally very highly regarded!

author: LAPhill
content: Action Strings is fine if you want to work off a recorded phrase, though I've found that the tempi in which it sounds good is pretty limited. There are other libraries, like ones made by a company called Performance Samples, in which the short notes are cut from longer phrases, which theoretically improves realism. There are drawbacks to this approach as well, but when it works, it's fabulous.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
We’re discussing at what point it cheapens it imo. 

Baking a cake from sugar, flour… it’s pretty much your cake (without entering the flour mines). 

Buy cake kit with precooked bottoms, you put jam and frosting on? Maybe a bit less your cake. 

Premade cake but you put Oreos on it? 

Premade cake but your write your name on it?

Or my fav, entirely premade cake but you take a dump on it? 

All but the last one will be tasty. But perhaps your aunt Betty will be less impressed if she knows you only wrote your name on it

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Lemme know if I’m off base here, I think it makes sense:

Generally, we need to understand culture as a conversation. People should be making music all kinds of ways. People should also be talking about the merits of said art, and critique how it was and should be made.

That very conversation shouldn’t be waved away in relativism imo, and to the extent a piece of culture can be cheapened or improved by discussing the way it’s been made, that’s all fair game and part of culture.

- Music should be made in all kinds of ways.

- Music should be critiqued, shat on and elevated in all kinds of ways. If the way it’s made being discussed cheapens it in people’s eyes, that’s a valid part of the cultural conversation too

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Hey guys, recently me and a couple of friends went to the Gasometer buildings in Vienna which used to be old gigantic gas tanks and are now hosting shops, studios and concert venues. The reverb inside is quite remarkable, so we wanted to capture that sound. Recorded with 2 Shure KSM 32s in stereo. There is a bit of atmos/noise as we had to record it with people there walking by so it's not the cleanest samples ever but I think they still sound really cool and maybe could be useful sometime 🙂 
Unfortunately we could only record a handful of samples as we were shooed away by a guy there after 15 minutes because we didn't have a "permit". 
anyway, I hope this is OK to post here and I really hope some of you will like the samples and maybe even use it one of your productions in the future - feel free to grab and download em here:

author: Ross Fortune
content:
What @Bryan DiMaio said.


1) 
I do 
dry LV
dry BV
LV FX
BV FX 

Then they can use them in any combo 

2) I’d tend towards separate. Presumably they have a daw so they can pick and combine what they need

3) mix bus on, except for anything like gullfoss

author: Eric Martin
content: for live use, I would remove most limiting/comp because live music will have a FOH to do the mix and things IMO should be more dynamic.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: okay, and in BV you have the doubles and the harmonies together? Or do you put the doubles in the lead?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
1. I usually build stuff from the start so that the leads + backings each have their own FX returns.
2. Usually separate harmonies + doubles
3. Depends on the mix bus. Sometimes everything has to go through the mix bus. Other times it's better/closer if it doesn't (Bloom, Gullfoss, etc). If the mix bus is just like EQ + subtle saturation, I'll copy those to each subgroup folder and then just bounce the groups all at once. Usually bypass the limiter because we're talking about a live PA w/ tons of power and there's not much need for transient reduction/density on the stems.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: thanks that makes a lot of sense. Is there any reason other than convenience for you to have different fx on the lead and bvs?

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: @Jonathan Jetter  @Eric Martin @Ross Fortune @Bryan DiMaio thanks so much for your insightful answers these helped a ton!

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: The phenomenon of push and pull was important enough that the old world had words for it...  Rubato, Ritardando, Acellerando...  sure we can program clicks to simulate the intended expression...   but letting good musicians play can be more magic than Photoshop Studio Methods can manage.  Sometimes the vibe is off because the click is on....  imho.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: ....  the original line of thinking is more that working to a Click has become too default in modern production.

author: LAPhill
content: And when I do film gigs, I'm often starting by finding a tempo that feels right for a scene. Unless it's really meant to feel rubato. Horses for courses, as they say.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Same...  but I like that method best for hard sync action or cartoon work. Definitely for commercials.  Randy's trick only happens (for me) during drama/dialog/background work.

content: Being a pioneer and having something to offer the scene is / was everything .

author: spectrummasters
content: After I’d already released productions in garage and U.K. funky I must have spent a year sending tunes to one of the scenes founders. I really wanted him to support my music .

author: spectrummasters
content: Despite being a close pal of my manager/label boss ….he’d never acknowledge my emails , never play my music in a club or on his radio shows

author: spectrummasters
content: One day my phone rang and it was him telling me well done . He’d been watching my development and not ignoring me but he wanted me to develop my own sound

author: chris_donlin
content: Re: the tony berg stuff. I personally don’t mind gatekeeping techniques. To me it’s no different than companies keeping trade secrets or restaurants hiding recipes. It can be a fun challenge to try to emulate something you heard and sure maybe you get close to that sound, but maybe instead you innovate something cool for yourself. I would also guess he’d be gracious to share in a more closed off way

author: chrissorem
content: I’d also agree with the gate keeping. Nothing to get mad at if someone doesn’t want to share what took them half a lifetime to figure out. Many people these days have expectations that one should share all they know with strangers, most of these people didn’t have anyone hand them anything. Consider it lucky and generous when someone shares something that took them years to figure out. Also it’s fun to try and figure things out on your own and often you will come up with your own unique way of doing  things

author: hyanrarvey
content: I got a trick for you for this. track it as a stereo channel Di on the left, amp on the right. use a plugin that can force it down to mono, mute the di in that plugin. then you're looking at the di but hearing the amp and you don't have to worry if you accidentally ungrouped while editing/tracking

author: bobby k
content: New thing I’ve been doing that I call “producer broth” (open to suggestions on this name). Came from the idea in restaurants when they take all the food scraps and boil them into a broth. When I’m putting together parts on a record and it starts to feel too busy, instead of muting the ones I don’t love I put them in a bus together that’s like -30db and has one of those long atmospheric verbs fully wet on it. Then now I have a big soft drone that can plop behind parts of the record and act as a glue or like a wash on a canvas.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is a good principle to keep in mind. I've got strong opinions on musical taste and you don't want to make the mistake of trying to please me. Popular stuff is popular for a reason.

For those who don't know, this is the type of music I'm referring to. The typical corporate training video vibe. I said it mostly tongue-in-cheek and I don't think Rob is in any danger of doing something like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9HUzWj-sSWw&list=RDQMUvZwSAFcomo&start_radio=1

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s just important to remember who it’s for, and not try to be too selfish with it. 

A year or two ago I was commissioned to make a TikTok sound for a large company. We gave em 3 cool ones and one that sounded like C grade Gangnam Style, because I knew that’s what they wanted.

Of course they picked the cheesy obvious one, and I was told a year ago it’s racked up nearly 10 billion plays. 

Overthinking is the curse of the talented person that languishes in mediocrity. Music doesn’t always have to be challenging. Sometimes it’s alright to just make the people feel good.

author: cian riordan
content: I'll always start by duplicating without the inserts, and starting with an EQ going into a compressor. Get it up to level with the original chain then A/B to see if I can pick out the big, broad stroke differences and try to re-create them with my own tools. If I don't get anywhere within 5 minutes I'll revert to their chain and then start tweaking.

I'm hearing a medium-slow attack time with a deep-ish threshold setting to give that super-pointy attack. Then a med-slow release time for it to swell back up on the sustain. But the volume of the sustain is pretty much pinned, so perhaps it's a parallel compression.

author: chrissorem
content: Fellow producers, how do you keep track of points on a record  to make sure you are being paid out correctly?

author: hyanrarvey
content: You gotta audit the label sometimes

author: cian riordan
content: A few ways. Some labels are cool and just send you checks quarterly. Most aren't and you'll need a manager or attorney to reach out on your behalf. There a few new online services that take a sizable cut (20-30%) but will amass all of your contracts in one place and they'll go hunting for money you're owed.

author: cian riordan
content: I spoke with these guys a little while ago and they know what they're doing. You just have to be OK with the sizable cut they take (for me, it was 15% of income, 30% of found income)

author: chrissorem
content: Huge thank you!  Yes some labels just send me checks but I never really knew how to keep track and seems like it’s the honor system

Question to producers: 
What’s your favorite production you’ve recreated for practice, and what insights and/or skills did you acquire from it?

If you’re a Google chrome user there’s also this extension https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/sample/kpkcennohgffjdgaelocingbmkjnpjgc

author: Brian Reynolds
content: Another idea to think of. Instead of figuring out how to control the room, control your focus. You can train yourself, put on a TV with volume while you work alone. Something like CNBC, with just monotone talking. And learn to work through it. Your mind and ears will get comfortable with zoning out the surrounding noise. Like a NBA player at the free throw line during a tense game. Same brain muscle thing

author: Slow Hand
content:
Whenever we're comparing today's art to past art it's important to keep in mind that every era has a lot of hot trash. But the subpar records get forgotten, while the cream rises to the surface over time. We now get to look back at the 1970s and cherry pick all of the amazing stuff that endured and forget about the bad stuff.

The same is going to happen for this current moment. We're being exposed to a lot of subpar records and a few great ones every year, and over time we'll forget about the wack stuff. So there's a bit of perceptual bias that we have to keep in mind when comparing to our current moment in time.

That said, if someone is still incapable of finding amazing records today then maybe they need to keep searching.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Hmm, I think I didn’t express myself clearly enough (English is not my native language). I’m not saying everything is better now just because it’s new. In fact, my personal belief is that, like any art form, it constantly evolves through different eras while maintaining a certain continuity within that broader evolution—if that makes sense.

I don’t think painting during the Renaissance was better or worse than during Impressionism. I can love Rembrandt and Degas at the same time. The same goes for music.

Also, I want to emphasize that those kinds of questions are totally valid and necessary—I just don’t like the way he approaches the topic.

There are great examples of stellar conversations about this subject from a healthier perspective. You and Ruairí are great examples of that.

P.S. I’m the kind of weird guy who usually prefers newer records from old bands, haha. For example, Failure—I freaking love their last two records even more than the classic Fantastic Planet from ’97!

author: Josh Bowman
content:
This just unlocked something in me-

When I read the word "love" in the context of taking about music and on the discord, i am thinking of it more like "to like, or enjoy" etc... maybe the way someone who hasn't experience really true love in the context of a long term relationship (romantic OR platonic) might think of love. I love some of my friends, sometimes some of them do things that might cause me to dislike them for a time or a moment, but I still love them. I cant express how profound this connect is. I love the work, but i dont always like it. Love takes real effort to cultivate and maintain. My brain just exploded a bit.

author: Juliette
content: Is it correct for me to route mono tracks to a stereo bus? I always get different sounds when routing to a stereo bus versus a mono bus. (but alas, whatever gives me the Width ™️ , that's what I end up going with)

author: Juliette
content: Recording stuff in mono and then routing to stereo scares me. It feels like I'm doing something wrong and I don't know why LOL

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nope. I can't think of too many reasons there would be any problem sending a mono track to a stereo buss. It's totally fine and I do it all the time.

If you want to be a little more specific describing the situation (and tell us which DAW you're using) we can help you reason through it, but - in short - you're probably fine.

author: Juliette
content: Good to hear! I'm quickly learning that track width is really just slight differences rather than actually quad tracking ahaha

author: Iwan Morgan
content: You are not doing anything wrong. This is how 99.9% of mixing/recording consoles are set up: a mono source comes into the desk and is assigned to the main stereo output/bus. the pan knob allows you to place that mono sound in the stereo field.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content: Concise list hater here. I find the best way to feedback music or videos is to record a 'reaction video' or reaction audio and explain your thoughts as you go in nuance. People misinterpreting concise lists is a massive issue. Looks good, is bad (imo).

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
I'm glad you felt that way! I've yet to have any collaborators or employees express dislike for it. If I were to improve it I could probably edit them down, I do that on occasion if it gets too long winded.

Me & a youtuber friend did many passes of feedback per day on nuanced things in videos and songs and it was a pain. He showed me Loom which is a video tool a lot of corporate people use for feedback, so we adapted our own methods. Much better outcomes, but takes a little longer to take in than a list

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is what compressor are for! 

But for very dynamic songs like this, I’ll track parts separately. Do ALL the whisper parts, then all the big parts, and I’d set my levels differently for each. 

I’m curious what’s the discord has to say on input levels, but I generally hit around -10 to -5 on the big moments

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Insane. At one point -18 was conventional wisdom but I don’t think it’s matter much anymore. Just don’t clip unintentionally and don’t be afraid to change settings for different parts of the song.

author: Juliette
content: Changing settings unfortunately only scares me because the mixing becomes a bigger, looming monster for me in the future. A learning experience that I always take on but never fully grasp.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Changing the settings should make mixing easier…

author: Juliette
content: One would think but I somehow manage to make it harder. I’m really just focused on the gain— I don’t really like fooling with it because the WA47jr is quite sensitive in nature. I’m still trying to find the sweet spot in terms of settings for it.

author: cian riordan
content: Honestly, as long as you’re not getting any digital clipping, you’re doing everything right. I would set the level very conservatively then have a low latency plugin compressor to help level things out.

author: cian riordan
content: Down the road, an analog compressor on the way into your interface will do more of this heavy lifting for you — but it’s totally not necessary.

author: cian riordan
content: Would be honestly safer — if you’re going to shoot for -18 on input — is to just have a low latency compressor plugin on the track so you can bring the levels back up to normal operating level. Also a chance for the singer to hear compression if there’s no hardware available.

author: Juliette
content: Thank you for this! I never really thought about the volume aspect of my headphones. I am constantly messing with my headphone volume during tracking, but never with the gain. Maybe I should be working the other way around?

author: Eric Martin
content: What would you say is the measured average level C-weighted of -8 in the room while you’re tracking? 85db? If he’s setting -18 to equal 85db C Weighted, then the level of the sounds @Deleted User will be making are identical just the gain staging is different, his Spotify playback might come in louder and have to get gained down but ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: cian riordan
content: I guess im saying that in order to get a -18dBFS signal up to 85dB, you’re gonna be cranking your speaker gain /headphone level and that’s gonna be dicey if something comes in full signal or you accidentally switch inputs.

Another new thing I’ve been trying and really liking is to send the panned sounds/instruments to a verb together, usually a room verb. It helps glue them together a little bit and makes things fee a little less stark.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yeah not as it was meant back in the 00s & 10s. “Overproduced” used to mean not raw or authentic enough; too much “studio magic.”

Now studio magic is ubiquitous, and I hear a lot of records / record makers tryna find ways to make things sound worse but feel better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! I'll often throw an instance of EchoBoy Jr. before my reverbs at 100% wet and 0% feedback. Then I can do all of the following:

1. Tempo-sync my reverb pre-delay.
2. Use the tone profiles to color the signal going into the verb.
3. Apply a ping pong pan to the pre-delay.
4. Apply saturation to the signal going into the verb.

author: Slow Hand
content:
An acquaintance once told me about a gig he had playing sax at the local strip club. The owner hired him to blow over the music in the club. The problem, he told me, is that the soundtrack was all Motley Crüe and Rob Zombie.

He explained that it was really awkward when he had to stand near the dancers and the clients when they were getting private dances.

If the thought of that doesn't make you want to break a saxophone over your knee, then I don't know what will.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Oh that’s cool. So we’re guessing the left and right always have polarity flipped, but the haas delay is initially long enough to perceive the left first then the right as if they’re discrete sounds. 

But as the delay shortens and the panning of each turns towards centre, the cancellation increases until that apex?

Cool.

author: Slow Hand
content: L/R polarity stay the same. Then you increase the delay time of one channel. At the apex, the delay time would be at it’s longest. Maybe 50 ms. That would be the first thing I’d try.

author: Slow Hand
content: But hey, try flipping polarity while you’re at it.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Sounds like you already are approaching this in a high integrity way. I’d just add some general thoughts: lean into the discomfort and tension there. Lack of ease doesn’t mean you’re on the wrong path. Could mean you’re stretching the boundaries of where you’re comfortable as a producer. Check any frustration at the door. Frankly imo don’t make the “viable” record that sounds boring af. Bringing in a new musician / collaborator can sometimes be just the shake up you need. Might be worth taking some risks between now and Wednesday.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
A good time to learn how to "put more stuff in the track" at a faster pace. Getting ideas down quickly is a huge part of being a great producer in 2025. 

If he's convinced that more stuff in the track will reveal the idea being good (or not), then do it. If you're working on one song, that should be doable in a matter of hours.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
There are a lot of ways to quantify what makes someone "good" at record making. But one thing that makes the seasoned pros different from the young and talented is knowing hundreds of little things like this. 

It's rarely the one little thing that makes your records great, but the accumulation of dozens of them at once can be very powerful.

author: Will Trotman
content: Ok cool, would you be bypassing the mixbus or bouncing through it?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
That can be a tough one, if you're doing a ton of program-based stuff/lots of gain reduction, when you solo something that doesn't trigger all that and bounce it, the sound may change. If you don't have a way to externally sidechain that stuff to the full mix it won't stack up the same way.

If you're not doing anything too crazy though it should be fine, and at the end of the day there are days when we don't need perfect objective accuracy. Do what feels better in your situation

author: Slow Hand
content:
Since we're (generally) discussing the absence of room tone, here's a fun fact: The percussion on this record was recorded outdoors. The story goes that Tom was trying to replicate the sound from a recording of pygmy musicians, but they just couldn't get it. Eventually someone had the thought to take it outside the studio. And there it was!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kh2m3_2mteY

author: LAPhill
content: Fair enough, though I think that's actually the rub for me. Telling someone who doesn't know about orchestral programming to "automate" is not going to solve the problem. You'd likely start reaching for volume automation to get things to fit, wihch is way less important than mod/dynamic. And for that kind of piece, you need to program the dynamics and volumes like a performance for it to sound natural, not just "turn things up or down"

author: LAPhill
content: So I push back because it feels like unhelpful advice for someone that's not used to using CC data, but it looks cool in a reel

author: LAPhill

author: LAPhill
content: Yeah, clearly plenty of very successful people are using it just fine. I used to use Logic, before it had that combination view, and dreamed of having multiple CC lanes visible. But.. not like that. Not like that.

author: LAPhill
content:
Why not both? Rob's a smart and musical guy, so I'm sure he can intuit a lot of things once getting his hands on them. But we talk a lot about pointing people in the right direction, solidifying first principles and best practices here, so I see only benefit in looking into how the tools are intended to be used.

"Treat it like a performance" is great once you know how it works and how to perform it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Is the production note is “needs more bounce,” where does your brain go?

author: Slow Hand
content: My first thought: More dynamics in the overall feel, or the timing of some parts may be out of pocket in some way.

author: Slow Hand
content: Second thought: Control the note lengths better. Could be that some notes need to be shorter or ending/cutting off in a way that is rhythmically attuned to the track.

author: Slow Hand
content: That can help the track feel "lighter".

author: Slow Hand
content: Especially in the bass, the way the notes are articulated and end is super important to the feel. It's subtle, but it's the difference between a track feeling light and bouncy, or simply heavy.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll often do clean up during periods where I need a break from concentrating so hard.

For example, if I need a break from tracking, I'll switch gears by doing some clean up for 5 minutes. It gives my mind a break, but I'm still knocking out stuff that needs to happen. After a few minutes of clean up I'm refreshed, and ready to re-focus on tracking (or whatever the main task is).

author: austenballard
content: I think we can all agree the important thing is making sure stuff is named clearly and in an orgnaized fashion tho

author: Slow Hand
content:
Technically your way will still sort properly, but when you inevitably forget to include an underscore between *v01_260216* then the file may get lost in the list.

**Edit:** The version is a subset of the date, so the higher classifier (the date) comes before smaller classifiers (the version # for that date).

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Speaks to something I've been thinking about a lot lately with AI etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Only hard things have value

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If a task becomes push button, one click, easy it's value trends to zero

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The example I always use is the Alchemists. Their goal was to turn lead into Gold. But if they'd ever actually suceeded Gold's value would have dropped to almost nothing

author: cian riordan
content: Or they figured it out and never told anybody.

author: cian riordan
content: Love the analogy though.

author: cian riordan
content: This was my big realization when starting to work with EV years ago and it kinda broke my brain. His inability to take shortcuts, to do something the easy way.

author: cian riordan
content: All born out of care and desire to do the best possible job.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And the difficulty, other people's avoidance of those details and struggles is what imbued his work with real value (artistically and commercially) - along with taste, skill, interpersonal abilities etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Hard for hards sake is a dead end, but the reality is that whatever prize you are seeking in this music game is probably on the other side of something (or many things) that are hard to do

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: My job has consistently gotten harder year on year for decades

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
I think the problem is that it's too tempting for folks to just do the easy things and call it a day.
Just look at the over reliance a lot of folks have on asking an LLM for answers before putting in any sort of effort researching and actually learning something, while receiving a hallucinated answer they aren't knowledgeable enough on the topic to call out when it's incorrect.

Instant gratification en masse isn't great imo

author: austenballard
content:
that's fine, it's human nature. most people for most of history have been mostly ignorant and concerned with getting by doing the easy thing

i don't think those of us in this server are here because we want to live in the middle of the bell curve, though. i know i don't.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Not saying some creature comforts are a bad thing, I like when gear gets out of my way because then I can focus on the music... but I think a lot of my best learning moments are from when I had to overcome something

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I'm just saying that if you want upside - money, cred, statues, more work etc then you need to go to the frontier where things are hard

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That's what other people won't or can't do

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That's where the value is

author: austenballard

I don't really think it's a matter of value judgment as much as acknowledging emergent properties in action

when many hard things become easy, they compound together to make new hard things possible

I would argue that the way you have been lowkey revolutionizing mastering  with RX (at least according to what I heard from @Slow Hand once) and your other techniques are that principle in action

author: austenballard
content: (which of course would be why you can speak with authority on the importance of doing the hard thing)
